Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I have my IUD inserted on 10/05/18. I had the Mona Lisa treatment for 3 years but I was getting long periods of 7 days with spotting a couple days before. My doctor suggested that I try kyleena to reduce period length and bleeding amount. Insertion was fine, just like for the copper one. Cramping for 2-4 hours and spotting for 2 days. Nothing for 2 weeks and spotting has appeared today with light cramping. Looking forward to seeing what periods look like. Try it, every body is different and therefore listen to it, nobody knows your body better that you!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I recently got on Kyleena. It's been a month and everything has been great. I'm a mother of 2 children. They're only 10 months apart so we needed a birth control that would be effortless. I'm not great at remembering to take a pill at the same time every day so the Kyleena IUD gave me that easy alternative while giving me the same pregnancy prevention. When I went to get it inserted my doctor scared me a little saying I was going to feel some bad cramps but I actually didn't feel anything but pressure. I haven't had any cramping at all since I got it. I've had some light spotting that only comes off on the toilet paper and I've also had a little bit of clear/whitish discharge. It's not a lot but it's there. It hasn't messed with my moods and I suffer from depression but it's not interfering with my antidepressants. Also I haven't lost or gained any weight or had any acne. So far so good

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I am 20 years old with no kids, and I had Kyleena inserted about a year ago. The insertion I remember was painful for a short period of time, like one large intense cramp, but totally worth it. As far as I could tell, I haven’t had any noticeable side effects, other than my period cramps going away and my period totally stopping (the best part!). I may have even lost a few pounds, not sure if it is related to the BC or not, though. The only iffy thing I have noticed is losing more hair in the shower I think it has gotten thinner. Also not sure if that is BC related. More so, decide to get this on your own based on the doctors’ facts, not by reviews from others because everyone has a different experience.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I've had Kyleena since July 2017. Insertion was not bad because Kyleena is much smaller than other IUDs (but lasts 5 years). I had spotting/discharge every day for 6 months, and haven’t had periods since (almost a year with no period) except one week randomly. I’ve had no changes regarding weight gain or acne. It’s possible it has resulted in weight loss for me since I haven’t had to exercise to maintain my normal weight since I got it.My only concern (aside from the initial spotting every day) is that I’ve had a very low sex drive. It’s not awful to the point that I can’t, but I don’t desire it and it takes a lot of warming up.Overall, happy with it.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Got my kyleena in April 2018 so I’ve had it for about 6 months. Insertion was incredibly painful and I did vomit but it’s different for every single person, as you can see on this thread. Overall, kyleena is convenient and a great form of birth control. However, I have gained 17 lbs since insertion with no change to diet or exercise routine except now I have started exercising more. Still gaining about a lb a week. I also have insane acne on my chin and back that I never had previous to Kyleena. I’m strongly considering switching to Paragard just due to the weight gain alone but I’ve heard horror stories about Paragard also so I’m kind of at a loss. I have stretch marks everywhere and it’s really throwing me off because I’ve always been in pretty good shape. Everyone is different and I would really recommend aside from the weight gain.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):Implanted at 8 weeks pp. - Slight cramping + spotting, but easier than I expected. I soon began to have mild irritability + impatience, mainly toward my husband and baby. I assumed it was work stress and being tired.2 months of Skyla - mild irritability became something much worse. I had negative intrusive thoughts. I looked at my beautiful daughter and felt nothing but a sense of obligation. I constantly snapped at my sweet husband. I had 24/7 anxiety about anything and everything. Even my worst PMS was nothing like this. The dealbreaker came when my baby was crying one night, and I yelled at her to shut up. (That’s painful to even type right now.)I had Skyla removed 2 days later. Within 3 days, I was stable, calm, + patient. Most importantly I felt love toward my baby again. I 100% believe that I had a negative reaction to this IUD, and that it made me feel psychotic. Removing it was the only change I made, and I’m my normal self.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I have had my skyla for almost a year now. I vaguely remember insertion, uncomfortable and some pain but nothing I regret. As for positives. Sex is great without condoms, and my periods are not as heavy as they use to be. However, my issues that I have had are pretty substantial.  I had consistent bleeding for the first 7 months. Not heavy but enough to have to wear a liner or tampon. With cramping the first few months. Since the 7 months I get a light period every couple of weeks very inconsistent  (sometimes for 2 days, sometimes for 2 weeks). I have gotten an ultrasound to make sure it didn't shift, and its seemed fine.  They suggested maybe I have a bleeding disorder but blood test seemed ok as well. AND lastly, the past few weeks I have noticed that if I tense up too much (like during orgasm ) that I get a sharp pain, not sure what that is about...Sorry about all that info, just my experience. I'm not sure If I will keep it or get it removed

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I have had Skyla for 2 years. It’s the best decision I have ever made regarding birth control. Many reviews spoke about how horrible the pain is when inserted, which is a 100% accurate. However, I experienced this kind of pain from my period which was way worse than that 60 seconds of a pain.if you don’t usually cramp with your periods, than you are in for a rude awakening when the IUD is first inserted. My doctor requires an ultrasound when inserting the IUD to properly place it (Unlike some doctors who blindly put it inside you which is so dangerous!!). I noticed when I stood on my feet more than 10 hours I would get unbearable pains. I felt like throwing up because they were so bad. However these pains stopped around 5 months. I've never had mood swings, weight gain or an increase in acne!! My periods were very light at first but now I can go months without a period or slightly spot for a week or two. I have no complaints as of today! The benefits definitely out weigh the cons!

Mirena (levonorgestrel):I have endometriosis so my doctor suggested switching from Nexplenon to Mirena so that the hormone will be directly released in my uterus and alleviate the awful cramping I get maybe 3-4 times a year. The insertion was really painful for me. They said I would feel instant cramping three times but after the last, it just persisted all day. They had to monitor me for about an hour because I got very dizzy, nauseated, and weak. I was given a pill for the nausea and a shot for the pain. Was told to not take ibuprofen for the next 8 hours after the shot. I was in awful pain all day. It’s been a week now and I still get waves of serious cramping. I have to take 2-3 pills of ibuprofen (200 mg) and use a heating pad. I’m considering getting it removed soon because instead of helping, it just induced more pain for me. That could just be because I have endometriosis and an prone to more painful periods.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I got the liletta inserted 11 months ago. No kids. It did hurt when they put it in but only for a few minutes and then I had intermittent cramping for a few days for which I took Aleve and put a heating pad on my tummy. I had intermittent cramping for a few months, mostly before my period which now lasts half a day (down from 7 days). I have gained 15 pounds though, even though I exercise everyday and eat really healthy. My face also breaks out, like a teenagers face. But I do like not having to worry about getting pregnant.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):Hi ladies, If you're thinking about Liletta, I wish to share my story since it would have been great to know this when I was evaluating my options. I had Liletta inserted after my postpartum about a year ago. First of all the insertion is painful and not pleasant at all. I had cramping and bleeding and it was not fun. However, that went away after about a week and I must say that I enjoyed this birth control. In June, I saw my OB and the IUD was doing fine. However, somewhere between June and October my IUD was nowhere to be found. My OB ordered a CT scan and guess what - the IUD was found OUTSIDE OF MY UTERUS! At this point, I have to have a surgery to get it out and who knows what the side effects will be from that. My point is not to scare anyone out there, but to educate so that you have all the information available. Please note - according to Liletta perforation is most common in breastfeeding women, which I was.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I was really excited to try the IUD since I had been on the pill for 5 years. Insertion was painful and uncomfortable but I felt fine a day after that. I bled and spotted for 3 months after insertion and now get my period once a month. I had high hopes for it but I became depressed, starting getting frequent headaches, developed acne, and experienced really bad PMS symptoms. I've been on it for 6 months and did not realize this form of contraception has a significantly higher risk of developing depression compared to other types. It contributes to mood swings and symptoms of depression. I am not usually prone to depression or anxiety and it has been through the roof since I got it. I used to never cry and now I cry over everything for no reason...This is just my experience and everybody is different.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I had the Kyleena IUD inserted today. I decided to go with IUD for a method of birth control and as a treatment for my adenomyosis. From the reviews I read online, I was terrified to go to my appointment & could hardly sleep. The insertion was not very painful, on a scale of 1-10 I would say about a 3-4. Now I am experiencing cramping, which is painful but Advil does help. I wanted to write this review to let other women know - do not let the reviews scare you! Especially for those seeking treatment from Endo or Adeno, the pain will be very minimal compared to what you are already experiencing, so do not rule this out as a treatment option.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I had it inserted on 10/12/18. My experience was great!There was a tv on the wall so I could watch the whole process via ultrasound. I was also on the last day of my period, with very light spotting. Beforehand I took Advil about 30 min prior to insertion and at the clinic I took a urine pregnancy test. I should mention that I am 23 and have never had a child, I’ve also experienced cystic acne as a teenager which has subsided now. The insertion was painful but not anything that was unbearable. Next the Kyleena device was inserted and extended when the arm were out I experienced sharp cramping and then another sharp painful cramp when it was pushed to the back of my uterus. After I had some cramping and took my time getting up. Then no issues at all! So far I have some regular period type cramps at night when I’m not moving around much before I go to bed, but when I’m active I feel nothing. I’ve had old blood discharge and spotting but it seems like that’s subsiding.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I had my Kyleena fitted for four months now and highly recommend it. I remember being SO worried about the whole process and whether my body would react badly to the device but I have so far had no problems. Insertion is uncomfortable but definitely bearable. Feels like an intense spasm / cramp but is over in a matter of moments. The after pain was no worse than period cramps. After a few weeks of minor spotting and bleeding (no heavier than my normal period) the bleeding stopped. After a month, I experienced no further bleeding which is great. This is a fantastic contraceptive method. I feel so much happier not having high levels of hormones in my body and do not feel as down as I did before. Highly recommend kyleena!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Ok I purposely waited to type my opinion because I wanted to give things a try, but I'm gonna be honest and not sugar coat anything. The procedure its self hurt like hell, but it was really quick. I felt a pinch and then a huge cramp and it was over. Later on I went home that night and I had cramps so bad that I thought I was gonna have to go to the ER. I usually do well with pain but this pain was a different kind of pain. Fast forward 2 months and I'm still randomly  cramping some days.  These cramps are sharp and painful. I still spot. My periods last more than a week which is annoying and now I'm starting to feel migraines, random depression, anxiety and weight gain is the biggest for me I have put on 15 pounds in a month. I usually exercise 5 days a week and eat very healthy. I'm about to make an appointment to take this thing out I cant take it . I hope you ladies have better luck than I did.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Let me just start off with say I love my Kyleena and it was the best decision I have made. I got it on March 1st, 2018. I was on my period when I got it inserted. There was some cramping when they put it in but thats only because they have to open your cervix. The bleeding stopped the day after I got it. Every once in awhile I’ll have light cramps but no bleeding. I do spot occasionally but not to the point where I need a tampon. Only see it when I use the bathroom. I haven’t had a period since March and it’s October! Also my acne has cleared up tremendously! I would highly recommend Kyleena to anyone willing to give it a try.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I’ve been on Kyleena for 3 months. Spotted for 2 weeks and haven’t had a period since. Had acne the first month but it went away. I have PCOS. I get some weird cramps around my ovulation and where my period would normally be on this but nothing too awful that ibuprofen and heat can’t fix. I have water retention mid cycle, about 5lbs,  but it goes away. Sex drive is lower but can still orgasm unlike on some birth controls. No mood swings what so ever. I use a 50/50 water and hydrogen douche when I spot a day around my period and haven’t had BV or a yeast infection which I got from Mirena, I also take probiotics. I have been on the pill and Nuvaring, both gave me terrible depression and killed my sex drive.  The copper IUD made me anemic after a year and threw off my liver function almost like a person with Wilson’s disease and immune system plummeted. I’d recommend trying Kyleena definitely but to each their own.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I've gained more than 6 kg from the moment I've started with Kyleena (I have it for like 4 months). I hadn't had any weight gain with Mirena, but with Mirena I was feeling numb. With Kyleena my sex drive improved, my skin is getting worse and as I already said, I've gained, and I'm still gaining a lot of weight. I don't eat unhealthy. Recovering from an eating disorder, so I know what I have to eat. I've already planned an appointment with the anasthesist to remove my Kyleena and getting a copper IUD.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):IUD's are a wonderful option for many women. Unfortunately something about it just did not react well with my body. Around months 4-7 the bloating, weight gain and mood swings especially irritability started to take over. I noticed a 7 pound weight gain around 4 months and suspected that the IUD was the culprit....but I was also going through some depression in earlier months which I thought maybe caused it instead. I was SO easily irritated and the bloating and rapid weight gain was effecting me so much that I didn't even want my boyfriend to touch me.  I gained another 6 pounds in 1 month. 13 pounds total. The bloating got worse and  Idefinitely felt myself gaining more weight. My doctor gave her 'medical opinion' but I was not myself so I got it removed. It's my 2nd day without and I am having little to no bloating which feels amazing and I definitely see an improvement in my mood and energy already. Great birth control for women who don't experience the negatives like I did...

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I had the Skyla for 2 Yrs and 1st I was VERY PAINFUL. The Dr. told me it wasn't painful but I  nearly passed out on the table while getting it inserted. I survived that pain and the next year  I had NO ISSUES. I went to my OB for my yearly check up and to our surprise the birth control couldn't be found . My Dr then used a camera and saw that it had wrapped around my cervix which was a reason why my legs went numb and I would have weird pains in my side, and as well I had start having blackout spells. I had been to a cardiologist thinking it was a heart issue and he could never find anything. OB discovered the IUD was wrapped around my cervix and I had to have it surgically cut out. I was no longer having numbness to the legs, heart paps and black out spells stopped and my body feels normal again. My Dr said that since Its smaller than all other IUDs it wouldn't migrate and It doesn't hurt during insertion but fact of the matter is she was wrong. I would make this my LAST CHOICE !

Mirena (levonorgestrel):The Mirena made me go crazy after only a month I got depressed severe anxiety and panic attacks. I was paranoid then ended up in a mental hospital. I had weird thoughts and felt like they would turn into actions. No dr helped except psychiatrist in the hospital told me it was the Mirena also the Zoloft they used to try to treat these symptoms that the doctor said was postpartum depression.  It was my first time on any type of birth control,  first time seeing a psychiatrist  or taking any antidepressants. I asked every dr can it be the Mirena? They all said no or I doubt it even though these are all listed side effects. I had the  Mirena taken out stopped taking Zoloft, now on no other meds now  and my life is back to normal. Thank goodness I was smart enough to listen to my body. The psychiatrist  said they get a lot of women in there for the Mirena. I could have lost my husband and 4 children my job my house all because the drs want to encourage you to keep it!!!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Don’t let the stories of the insertion scare you. I was expecting and slicing or cutting feeling but it just felt like an intense cramp for 5 seconds, and then normal period cramps for the rest of the day. IUD’s are amazing because you never have to worry about them. I had a few experiences where I had sharp, painful cramps out of no where (I never used to get cramps before) and my acne has gotten bad, which is why I’m thinking of switching. However, it is so convenient that I might just justify keeping it in and suffering through the hormonal acne. My periods are irregular and my bleeding is normally old blood. I have also experienced anxiety, frequent UTIs (which I combat by taking a cranberry pill everyday) but it’s hard to tell if the IUD is causing it or not.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I got Skyla and it’s great. I was so scared because so many reviews said it was the most painful experience, but it wasn’t that bad, and I haven’t had any kids. I think the worst part was literally right after they were done putting it in and my body didn’t know what was in it, but after a couple hours I felt like nothing happened. I hardly have a period.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I had kyleena for about 6 months until I decided to take it out. For the first 3 months I had dark brown discharge daily with brown specs in it , also accompanied by occasional sharp cramps. After the horrendous discharge experience was over, I was greeted with another issue, chronic yeast infections that I would get every month, sometimes twice a month. I would go to the doctor and get medicine to treat it , it would work then a few days after the treatment , I would get the same symptoms all over again.The side effects weren’t worth it , my vagina was always irritated , swollen, itchy or inflamed. I never used to get this much yeast infections prior to the IUD , I’d get 1-2 max per year which is normal but when it turned into an every month thing I decided to take it out. Also I experienced nausea, headaches, lightheadedness & tender breasts... I almost fainted a few times due to the lightheadedness. Proceed with caution on this one. Do your research.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Hi I'm from London, mother of 2 , I got the Kyleena from the sexual health clinic on 20.9.18. The insertion wasn't bad few cramps and then cramping and aching for next 2 days but had to lie down and take it easy. I was on my period when I had it inserted but I've been having light bleeding ever since then every single day!! It is annoying but I'm going to wait 2 months before trying something else. My doc did say I can have the pill on top if its too much bleeding but I don't want any more hormones. I did get some headaches for 2 weeks after but these have gone now and not sure if they were related to the IUD. Overall no acne yet, I used to have implant in my arm that gave me bad acne! However so far other than bleeding I'm happy with it.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I got the skyla IUD inserted 6-7 weeks after my cesarean. I previously had the Mirena and the paraguard. Let me tell you! The skyla is supposed to be smaller but it was the worst pain I've ever experience in my life,  keep in mind that I've had the other IUD inserted which hurt but nothing like this one. I was in tears the whole time! I was sweating and for the fact I had jumped up when my cervix was being measured they had to remeasure again and the process took longer. Almost 8 1/2 months later my periods last 2 weeks every month. I gained 6 pounds right after the insertion and I workout like crazy. If I can go back on the paraguard I would but since I got pregnant 2 x in a 8 month period after 5 years of being on it I can't. Goodluck!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I am glad that I didn't read any reviews or look up pictures before having this done.The insertion was extremely painful (way worse than any of my piercings or tattoos) but over far quicker. The only moment of "I can't handle this" pain was just as it was inserted, & then it was done. No kids  she explained that wouldn't change the pain level, which was reassuring. I did feel faint for a few minutes after, but then I was perfectly fine to drive home. The cramps were the worst after effect- I'm thankful for Midol & my heating pad. The first 16 hours they were almost constant, & then the  following 20-24 hours they more mild. After that, no significant pain or discomfort. Bleeding (after day 2) was all old blood & lasted about 8 days. Day 12 in the evening I had the worst cramping I'd had so far, it lasted a couple of hours, then following day were mild cramps, nothing worrying. If this works out, I will be very thankful. I guess by month 6 I'll know-I have high hopes.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Update on my review** from 2018-09-18 It has been a month now.I want to get it removed. I am having random strong cramps during the day OR night, it's to the point where I'm crying and almost vomiting. Having migraine also.  The spotting is there but I don't think it's that bad. I have experienced acne, previously I have NEVER had acne . Most of the time, I feel dizzy and light-headed ,I don't want to get out of my bed anymore. I have never been this tired.  After work, I'm shaky I almost can't walk. I have terrible back pain and leg pain as if I was constantly in my period. In the morning, I have difficulty to eat because I always feel like puking until 9am ,and that is since the day of the insertion. I just do not think the IUD is for me.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I had the Liletta put in at my 6 week post natal appt in March 2018. The pain was so bad that I fainted at the check out desk on my way out! Shortly after insertion, I started having 2 periods a month and constant cramping. My stomach also felt so bloated all the time enough so that at 9 months post partum, I was asked twice if I was pregnant again! I also had zero sex drive, sex was uncomfortable, and I just felt angry all the time when I’m normally a really positive person. Also, in the 6 months of having it, I almost gained all my baby weight back and couldn’t lose weight for the life of me. I could not figure out what was happening! Due to the cramping, I decided to have it removed and just happened to look at these reviews around the same time. I am 99% sure all my symptoms were due to liletta. Since removal my bloating is gone, I’m down 5 lbs, my sex drive is back and I just feel happy again. I think I’m done with hormonal birth control!

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I’ve had the skyla for about a year and 8 months now. Everyone I spoke to who had an IUD said that the insertion was the most painful experience of their lives, so I was terrified going into my appointment. Fortunately, I didn’t find it to be terribly painful at all, and I haven’t had any kids. The cramps afterwards were pretty bad but stopped by the end of the night. It’s a very convenient form of birth control and I don’t regret getting it, but it took about 6 months for my body to adjust. I experienced ridiculous mood swings during the adjustment, as well as intermittent cramps and irregular periods (my cycle was pretty regular before getting the skyla). I spotted every day for the first month as well, very lightly though. Once I adjusted, however, I found my emotional PMS symptoms actually improved. Now I get pretty much regular, very light periods. Overall effective and convenient and I’m happy with it now...but the adjustment was truly terrible for me I must say.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I’m 19, & 115 lbs. Got Skyla in February 2018, was super painful getting put in but pain lasted only about 30 minutes. Everything was great for the first 4 months no period cycle just slight spotting, no pain... starting in June I began noticing my (almost always perfect) skin start to develop very large bumps. It was cystic acne. It snowballed from there my skin only got worse. My face was producing an abnormal amount of oil and the acne never seemed to let up. I tried many differenent acne solutions and changed my diet to more clean eating but nothing seemed to help. I just ignored it and thought maybe college is causing stress breakouts & it eventually will go away. I was wrong. In August I started experiencing severe cramping in my lower stomach. It came about every 5-10 minutes and was nearly everyday until I decided to get Skyla take out which was on Oct. 5.  The cramps immediately stopped. My acne is still bad considering it’s only been a couple of days.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Update: It’s been about a month now with my IUD. I’m very happy with it. However, I am going on almost 2 weeks with a period. It sucks but I expected it!! Definitely been experiencing menstrual cramps that are awful but I just take Tylenol and Advil! I also noticed I’m getting slight acne but nothing major. I’m hoping the bleeding will stop soon but when I was on the pill it took a while for my body to adjust. Again, I highly recommend getting it.... remember to take 4 Advil prior and ask your doctor about a pill to take the night before to dilate your cervix. It will help A LOT and not be as painful.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):Just got it yesterday, didn't feel a thing and didn't even feel cramps. It doesn't even feel like it's there. Walked out the office like nothing happened. But my doctor is great also. Everyone's experience will be different. Looking to see what the next 3 years would be like now. Good luck everyone!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Hello all, I have Kyleena insert 10/2/18 it was on my cycle. I had had two children by natural birth, so I felt a little cramp but I haven’t got anything else so far which is good> I think everyone body reacts differently to it, I'll keep you guys updated.

Mirena (levonorgestrel):I had mirena inserted May 4th 2018. Insertion itself wasn't bad but I did have some severe cramping for a few hours afterwards (to the point my uterus was sore for 3 days). If my body continues to adjustment well I plan on to keep using mirena until menopause but I'm going to give it  a full year before making that call and I'm 35 years old now. Pre-IUD period was for 4 to 5 days with no spotting in between.With IUD up till 3 months each period decreased by half but spotting for 14 to 16 days. Month 4 thru now is spotting for 14-16 daysAt this point the only thing is for duration to shorten or vanish to make this any easier. But so far I'm pleased especially since I don't have to remember anything other than to check the stings.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I had Skyla put in and a week later it had to be removed due to PID. I’ve never had vaginal issues (BV, yeast, STD) or anything before this was inserted. Day of insertion I had terrible cramps and nausea that did not let up. By day two I had no appetite, cried about everything (I’m a very happy positive person) and felt so uncomfortable in my own skin. My belly was bloated to the point where I looked pregnant. Day four I check my strings and my vagina is so swollen and sore I can barely get a finger in. Call OB next day and she says it’s probably an infection and to go to urgent care. Urgent care couldn't find the strings and sent me to ER. ER did an ultra sound and found that it was further up in my uterus than it should have been but they managed to get it out without too many issues. I’m now being treated for PID. Doc isn’t sure what caused it since I was tested for infections before insertion.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I've had my IUD for about 3 weeks now. I am quite shocked to see that some people passed out/vomited from the experience as mine was flawless, I was in and out of the Drs office in about 5 minutes. Sure, the insertion was painful, but not unbearable. I have also never given birth and I took ibuprofen prior to the appointment. I wasn't given anything to loosen the cervix. It felt like a sharp, extreme period cramp during the uterus measurement, and another similar sharp, extreme cramp for the insertion, which each lasted about 3 seconds. As soon as the insertion was done, the sharp pain changed to a dull pain which probably lasted for about an hour. I had some bleeding that day and some mild spotting for about 2 more days, and thats it. I get cramping on and off occasionally, but VERY mild, less than a period cramp, and it usually only lasts a few minutes. So for those reading these reviews and freaking yourself out, it's possible your experience will go just as smoothly.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Just got the kyleena early this morning and my experience was great I took a 600mg ibuprofen a half hour before appointment and didn't feel a thing just a little pressure but it was over in 2 mins not even was so fast. Loving it so far but it's only been a day hopefully this works out in long run for me !

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I’ve had kyleena about 1 year. Insertion wasn’t bad for me but I tolerate pain well after having kids. The first few months were rough- cramps, non stop bleeding, bad hormonal acne, mood swings, etc. I combated these symptoms with midol, my fav face mask, herbal tea and heating pads. I am so glad I stuck it out because my body must have acclimated and I haven’t had any issues for the last 9 months. No more acne, zero spotting or bleeding, and my horrible periods and cramps completely gone. 3 months of torture traded for almost 5 years of not having to worry about anything worth it to me. I have noticed that this makes me hungrier so I’ve had to be cognizant of that to avoid weight gain. I drink herbal tea to quell the hunger. Haven’t gained any weight though. After insurance I only paid $7. Couldn’t be happier with Kyleena.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I have had Kyleena for almost a year now and it is amazing. The insertion was very painful but only lasted maybe 10 seconds. Experienced cramps for the first 12 hours or so but have never had an issue since. My periods are much lighter (from a 7 day period to 3 days of very light spotting) and do not come as often. I have experienced acne on my chin and back but it is not awful and I'm not 100% sure if Kyleena is the cause. I highly recommend.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I really like being on Kyleena. It’s pretty much stress free as far as birth control goes, almost completely one and done.Insertion was pretty painful, partially because I had no expectation of it being painful so it was also a bit of shock. Felt okay after two days or so. I’ve been on for over 9 months and the cramps are pretty bad. Definitely worse for me than pre-iud cramps and not concentrated to having a period. For the first 7 months, my period was super light but really long, normally 1.5 to 2 weeks. At 8 months, my period lasted for about 4 hours. Quite the drastic change. Hoping to see it even out soon. Had slightly more acne than normal here and there but not constantly.Only other difficulty was for my husband. The strings poked him pretty painfully in most positions and it was pretty difficult to have sex at all. Kind of destroys the point of birth control. Had to go back in to get the strings tucked into my cervix. No problem after that.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I decided to get Skyla almost 5 months ago. The insertion was painful but nothing like what the reviews and stories online made it out to be. It was overall not a bad experience. I cramped pretty bad the day after but that was it. I have been spotting & cramping frequently and randomly since getting it but it is now starting to slow down. My acne just started flaring up this month though. Going to give it a couple more months to see if the spotting and acne become less of a problem. Overall I am happy about it though.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):Insertion hurt,  but I was fine afterwards with normal cramps for a couple hours. I've had it for about 3 months now. My skin broke out as I adjusted, and my cycle is still regulating or else I'm one of the people who will not get it anymore because I'm extremely late, (40 days since last period, not pregnant). The acne is clearing up but my breasts have been hurting badly for the past week and a half. They're incredibly tender and bigger. I'm hoping this will subside soon.I believe the hormonal changes are also affecting my mood as I adjust, but it's already getting better. I'm going to stick with it for a full year before I'd have it removed. I'm hopeful it will get better because the Skyla I had before this also took me about 9 months to normalize.I got this at Planned Parenthood and my insurance covered it.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I have had my skyla for about a month I have the worst uterus pains non stop spotting but I was already having issues with my bleeding so the bleeding is not a big concern it's the headaches and uterus pain that is the worst.  Also lately I noticed I get agitated so quick but the headache and uterus pain might be one of the major keys to that makes me get this out.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I am 18 years old never had a kid. I've had my Kyleena in for about 2 months, and I am getting it out next week to switch back to the pill. I was on the pill for 3 years and I wanted to change it up since I am in college now. The insertion was rough, wasn't as bad as I thought but it was pretty intense. I was okay with the IUD for the first week, then the cramps came, and I had severe every day ones to the point I would cry, hold my breath and almost pass out. I planned to keep it in for 6 months to a year to give my body time to adjust, but I don't think I can handle it anymore. I had my period for 6 weeks, had a week break, now I'm back on it and I have no idea when this will end. I also went from having normal to dry skin to becoming an oil pool. I have hormonal acne which I never have had before while taking the pill, and I feel so dirty. I  have weight loss of about 10 lbs. I can't gain back and I think I am still losing weight. My anxiety has gone up as well, and I have mood swings.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Hi guys! I posted awhile back talking about my experience. My insertion was not painful. It’s been about a month and a half and I’m experiencing such painful cramps. I’ve always suffered bad ones but these are horrible...has anyone else experienced this? I’m still spotting everyday... give me some insight

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I’m 47 years old. Had this birth control for since May 2018. Used to take the Depo shot. Insertion was no problem. I was fine at first. Over the year and a half, I have gained 30 lbs, depressed, tired, bloated, lack of sex drive and moody. I eat very well, work out and can gain pounds quickly and lose them slowly. My doctor didn’t think the BC was the cause. Ran tests for thyroid and pre-menopause and those tests were negative. I truly believe this BC is the cause and I plan on having it removed immediately. I haven’t had a period on over four years. So I don’t know what will happen. But I would rather deal with a period than weight gain.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I got Kyleena a month ago after years of being on the pill. Having never had a baby, insertion hurt. It wasn’t the most painful thing I’ve ever experienced, it was just a different kind of pain. It was uncomfortable, sharp, and crampy. The cramps calmed down for an hour after insertion but then came full force driving home. They were so painful I almost had to pull over on my way home. They continued throughout the rest of the day and were horrible. However, I have never had period cramps before this so I think I’ve been hyper sensitive to them. The next day I was fine and had no cramps for a week. After a week I would randomly get sharp cramps but I’ve had no spotting. I rarely get cramps now. My only real complaint is that I did get a bad yeast infection after insertion. All in all, insertion hurts and you may have to deal with being slightly uncomfortable for a bit while your body adjusts, but it’s well worth it to be in control of body!

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I LOVE it had it for about 6 years now, so yes once my third year was up I got a second one. I had the Mirena birth control first had a lot of pains with that one until my doctor recommended the skyla hardly get my period and myself haven't notice weight gain all though I do take care of myself, so get the skyla!!!!

Mirena (levonorgestrel):I have been a size 8 all my life, never putting weight on however after getting the Mirena Coil, I put on 3 stone that I could not lose despite belonging to a gym and eating very healthy.Other side effects included terrible mood swings , debilitating migraines, depression and anxiety, hair loss and some spots . I had never suffered with any of these conditions before the coil.Blood test show my hormones are totally out of whack which certainly explains my symptoms. When I had the coil out, the strings had been cut too short meaning I had to have an instrument pushing through my cervix into my womb, the pain was so bad I cried. I was NEVER told or advised  about possible side effects/removal issues.I think health care professionals push these things on to women without giving them all the objective information needed to make informed decisions over their own bodies!!!!

Mirena (levonorgestrel):I had mirena inserted about 9 weeks after having my first child. It was an awful experience.  The first attempt my dr spent 30 mins trying to insert it before she had us move to ultrasound dept where we spent another 45 mins trying with no luck. Apparently I have a "curvy cervix ". I went back 4 days later with a full bladder and pain meds and NSAID on board. We went straight to ultrasound this time and she spent 45 minutes to successfully implant it. Pain on day 2 was not so bad since I had pain meds in me. It's been 4 weeks now and I've bleed every day of that....some days heavy other days spotty. I hope it evens out soon however when I was on the depo shot I bled for 7 months straight before my period disappeared.I'm happy I have it because it's one less thing to worry a out but I do want to caution people out there that the insertion process may not be as quick and easier as others have experienced.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I absolutely loved it! The insertion was painful but that was expected. Immediately following the insertion was bad cramping but I took some Advil which helped. It was so worth it though seeing as it lasts 3 years! Before Skyla, my periods were extremely heavy and I  always experienced horrible cramping. But literally after a couple months with the IUD I only spot when I’m on my period and I have no cramps at all. My mood swings were pretty bad the first couple of months of Skyla but they eventually went away after while. And not to mention this birth control is definitely effective!!! I’m not trying another IUD that lasts 5 years:)

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I normally don’t review products online but I found that there isn’t a lot of information on this product and it is not very well known outside the US ( I’m in Australia ) .The insertion was the most painful thing I’ve ever experienced ( worse than broken bones and dislocated joints ) it lasted for about a week then I was fine for about 6 -10 months . I experience severe cramping and my periods were almost non existent ( doctor re assured me that I will continue to have normal periods ). After a year of having this IUD I developed severe anxiety that wouldn’t go away with anything !! Before this I never experienced a panic attack in my life . After 2 days I had it removed I started to feel somewhat normal again  . I’m not here to bash this product simply to share my experience . It did it’s job and I didn’t get pregnant but it is not for everyone. Please get informed before you make any decisions.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I am 28 and have had two children. I had my last baby a year ago now. My period had returned at 5 months after having baby. I thought insertion was uncomfortable, but bearable. Nothing as intense as back labor or giving birth. So far I took a little ibuprofen to help manage some mild discomfort and I’ve had some spotting. I’ll come back and report more about my experience in a few weeks.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I’m 18 yrs old, never had a child & on Kyleena for 2weeks.  I was not on my period for insertion and I was on the pill for 4 years prior to switching. I read many reviews before & was nervous for insertion/side effects. I took 800mg Motrin before appointment & was given 2 tablets of misoprostol to insert vaginally 2hrs prior. Insertion  of Kyleena wasn't nearly as bad as expected, only lasting about 20 secs & felt like a sharp pain. I was light headed, crampy & nauseous for about 12 hours following but cramps turned into intense pressure & light headedness subsided. I was nauseous for about a week after insertion. I did not start bleeding until 5 days after & it started as brown discharge before moving into a light bleed & back to discharge which now seems to be coming to an end. Overall, I'm so far happy with Kyleena & hope that all continues to go well. If you are contemplating getting this IUD, please give it a try, don’t let other reviews scare you because it truly is a different experience for everyone

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I have had Liletta for a little over a year and I am finally having it removed. I have wanted it removed for about 9 months and have had several doctors advise against it. Since beginning Liletta I have had severe cystic acne breakouts, heightened anxiety, depression, ovarian cysts, and weight gain. It had been one of the worst decisions of my life having this placed and had been an utter pain. I would not suggest this product to anyone. I read several reviews before having Liletta placed and tried to remain optimistic however this product did not work for me at all. The side effects greatly outweighed the benefit of having an IUD.

Mirena (levonorgestrel):Not impressed to find this IUD is no longer where it should be and has started to work its way out, meaning my contraception I thought was reliable has been useless.  One pregnancy test ( negative, thank goodness) and a lot of unnecessary stress I was asked if I would like another...NO WAY. Back to the depo injection for now.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I started my Liletta a week ago and so far so good. Haven’t experienced any crazy mood swings or any other side effects thus far. Will give another update later. I switched from Nuvaring to the contraceptive pill to this IUD.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I went & read the reviews while choosing between the Kyleena, mirena and Paragard. After reading I was terrified & had anxiety before my appointment. I wanted to share my experience bc it wasn’t bad. I was instructed to take a pain killer 1h before & took 1 ext strength Advil. I did a urine sample to confirm I wasn’t preg and my DR did a pap. I’m 30 yrs & have never had kids. The opening of the cervix was where I felt a bit dizzy. The measurement & insertion was the worst part. I felt cramping & pain but on a scale of 1-10 it was like a 4 or 5 at worst, & it only lasted maybe 10 secs. I felt perfectly fine right after & just have minor cramping & a little bleeding. If anything changes I will write another review. Don’t let the reviews scare you bc most women who have good experiences don’t go on here to write about it (naturally people are just more inclined to write a review when things go wrong). Bring someone you are comfortable with. It was helpful to have the support!

Skyla (levonorgestrel):HORRIBLE. The only thing that was great was It didn’t get my pregnant. I’m thankfully getting it out tomorrow. I’m PRAYING and HOPING that my mood, depression, anxiousness, and sadness goes away after it is removed. IUD’s work different for everyone. However I have never ever experienced something like this. Has anyone else had major issues like this?!

Skyla (levonorgestrel):HORRIBLE. The only thing that was great was It didn’t get my pregnant. I’m thankfully getting it out tomorrow. I’m PRAYING and HOPING that my mood, depression, anxiousness, and sadness goes away after it is removed. IUD’s work different for everyone. However I have never ever experienced something like this. Has anyone else had major issues like this?!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I’m on week three. Insertion was not that bad. Two days after the cramps were so bad. I had to pull over on the high way. Still cramping everyday. Now that I’m on week 3 it’s been better but I still get cramps. I’m still spotting as well. Emotionally I feel like a mess. I feel very depressed. My doc want me to try for a few months. But I think I’m gonna get it taken out.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I got liletta put in almost a week ago and so far have had a great experience! I am 20 years old and have never had kids. My period cramps are usually not too bad, I'll take a few Ibuprofen and they usually settle down, and my pain tolerance is pretty high. I knew going in that the insertion was going to hurt, however it definitely was tolerable. In the days following, I haven't experienced any heavy cramping (thankfully). The rest of the day after getting it inserted just felt like how I would normally cramp the day before I get my period. I took it easy the 2-3 days after getting it inserted however I feel completely normal now. I have a brownish/yellowish clear discharge but so far no heavy bleeding either. I wanted to leave a review just because the day before I got mine inserted I read the reviews and psyched myself out because they are almost all bad! Every body is different so I'm glad I didn't chicken out because so far so good!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):The insertion of the IUD was the most pain that I’ve ever experienced, but totally worth it. You feel a pinch when the device enters the uterus, after that there’s a really painful cramp. The cramp feels similar to a mini contraction. The pain only last for a few seconds. It was all worth it. I don’t have to worry about taking a pill every day or getting a shot every 3 months. The side effects that you read on the internet are generalized. The information that you find is basically talking about all progestin birth control. Not the IUD specifically. The IUD mainly effects the uterus (not in a bad way) Other methods like the pill and the shot can effect several parts of the body. A good example would be calcium depletion with longterm use of Depo. When on any form of birth control I suggest taking a probiotic daily to prevent a yeast infection and to prevent BV. I’m speaking from experience. Doctors and nurses don’t tell you these things.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I have had Kyleena for one year and it is great.  I am 42 with 2 children.  Doc used local anesthesia for insertion which minimized pain.  Got some really bad cramping about an hour after - took 2 advil and gone within 30 minutes.  Occasional yeast infection, but that would happen regardless. No issue with weight gain.  Cycles were 1 to 3 days longer than normal within first 6 months, but now have returned to usual 28 day cycle.  Hardly any bleeding post insertion or monthly - still get some spotting for 1 to 3 days but barely enough for a panty liner.  Lessened PMS symptoms as well.  No issues with weight gain, hair loss, acne, or mood swings. Definitely works as effective birth control that is effortless. Highly recommend.  Wouldn't read too much into negative reviews. Everyone reacts differently.  Pill never worked for me. Horrible weight gain, thick cervical mucous, and no sex drive.  This had no such effects!  Quite the opposite in fact!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):It's been 4 months since my IUD was inserted, so I'll explain how it's been so far.While I do love my IUD, it's causing me some stress. I have been experiencing acne, which wasn't really a problem when I was on the pill.. But also,  I have no idea when my period will be anymore. It's mostly gone away. That might sound great, and it would be! However, the rest of the month is spent with cramping followed by spotting. If I don't wear a liner every day, then I will need peroxide for my undies. It's all old blood too! Even during my period it's mostly old blood. I'm hoping it won't go on for much longer, because it's so annoying to be on my period practically every single day. Sometimes the cramps are so painful. They don't last long, but they're always followed by old blood. I do miss my pills because I knew when my period was coming and there were minimal side effects, but I have a greater peace of mind, so I'll stick it out. Hopefully it'll clear up in a few more months..

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I got Kyleena nine months ago. The insertion was painful. It took just a few minutes but felt way longer. I have a pretty good pain tolerance but almost passed out. I was fine immediately after, though - drove myself home from the clinic and didn’t experience any discomfort the rest of the day. I had a light but irregular period the first six months. I got cramps frequently too. They were about the same level of pain as my period cramps were pre-IUD. After six months, I’ve mostly stopped bleeding but still get really light cramps about once a month. I’ve had no side effects. I’d absolutely recommend Kyleena. The first six months were annoying but it’s been worth it since. Background on me: I’m 27, 5’8, 150 lbs and have never been pregnant. I’ve been on four different birth control pills and had bad side effects with all of them.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):The insertion hurt a little bit but only for a few minutes. After I had some cramping and discomfort for about 30 or so mins and I was really sleepy. But now I don’t feel a thing and I feel completely normal. I got my Kyleena inserted yesterday afternoon.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I get optic migraines and was searching for a non-systemic method of birth control, so I thought the IUD may be for me. My physician recommended Kyleena because I have never had children and it is the smallest available option (minimizes expulsion risk and cramps). Having it placed was very painful, and I did feel a little faint for about 5 minutes after it was placed. I cramped pretty badly for the first week so used ibuprofen around the clock per my physician's recommendation (still plenty of cramps despite that) until I was worried my stomach couldn't take ibuprofen anymore, then I slowed down taking them. The cramping lessened after about 3 months, but I still cramped significantly for several hours a day 6-7 days a week. I gave it a year, then decided I didn't want to live like that anymore. The cramps went away within 15 minutes of the IUD being removed. My physician said it is not uncommon for women who have never been pregnant to not tolerate IUDs.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I got kyleena inserted August 2017, so its been about 13 months post insertion. I am 22 years old and was previously on the combo pill for 5 years until getting kyleena. I was getting severe migraines with aura daily towards the end of my time on the pill so my neurologist made me switch to a progesterone only birth control. I originally wanted to get the copper IUD since theres no hormones... and honestly I wish I did.  I didn't find insertion that bad, I took 600 mg of ibuprofen 1 hour before my appointment.  I felt one big cramp, the pain only lasted 30 seconds. When I went home I just relaxed on the couch and had some moderate cramping for the rest of the night. Well come August 2018 I started breaking out in huge cystic acne. I had light acne as a teen but nothing like this! I also noticed that a lot of my hair has fallen out and the appearance of my hair has lost thickness and volume since having kyleena. I can't wait to get this thing removed in a couple of days

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I had kyleena inserted about 3 days ago. My experience was very different from everyone else’s. My cervix was stubborn and they couldn’t sound my uterus. They ended up using metal dilators to force my cervix open so they could sound and insert. Afterwards I couldn’t move for the rest of the day. The cramps that came afterwards were horrendous. I stayed in bed that whole day. The cramps that kept coming in waves woke me up from a dead sleep. Day two was a lot better. I felt different emotionally, but otherwise the pain had gone away and every so often throughout the day I would feel those painful cramps again. Day three was a lot better. I felt no pain through out the day my spotting continued but nothing a panty liner couldn’t handle.  So far so good with kyleena and I hope it continues doing good! Will post an update after 3-6 months

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I got the kyleena inserted almost 4 months ago, and I wrote a initial insertion review and now back for a follow up. So far I love the kyleena I actually lost 10 pounds since being on it, I don’t have any acne issues or any other problems. My periods are about two weeks long right now but it’s more spotting than anything so nothing that a panty liner can’t fix! So far I like it will check back at the 6 month mark!!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I got Kylenna inserted yesterday morning and it was terrible. The doctor during the procedure said  Sh*t that’s not good which made me really uncomfortable and nervous. I’m 18 I took the pills the night before to make my cervix softer and then I took Valium before the appointment and overall it was uncomfortable and the pain after was horrible. I had cramps all day and all night and again this morning. They did an ultrasound at the same time they inserted the IUD and that made the pain a lot worse cause the lady was pushing so hard and the man inserting it was having issues.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I got the IUD about 2-3 months after my son was born. As everyone else stated the insertion was a bit uncomfortable, but it wasn’t horrible. My menstrual cycle stayed about the same. Everything was fine until I got pregnant a little over a year of having it. Yes...I’m part of the 1%. My practitioner took the IUD out immediately. Not sure what’s to come next ,because my son is only 17 months old.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I've had the Liletta IUD for over a year and have been very pleased with it. The insertion felt like a small pinch for 20-30 seconds and wasn't too painful. I took advil afterward and had light spotting for 2 days. I've never had kids and was worried insertion might be more painful, but that was not the case. I whole-heartedly recommend the Liletta IUD.As a side note, I have noticed that I bloat more easily now from chewing gum which could be a side effect of the progrestrin. It hasn't bothered me too much though and is worth the effectiveness of Liletta. I also no longer have a period which is one of my favorite parts. I got my strings cut shorter so that I can feel them but they're not too long. Never had a partner say they can feel them either. I think it's weird others have had that experience.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I got kyleena a little over 4 months ago. The insertion was the worst pain I’ve ever experienced. I am 19 yrs old and have never had children or anything. I took two Aleve before the insertion and afterword I had pretty mild cramps. I bled for about the next month and a half and had really terrible cramps daily. After about two months of having kyleena my bleeding stopped and my periods generally were less painful but longer. Now that I am on month four I completely love it. My last two periods came on time and they were painless.  One thing to note when you get an IUD make sure to stay on top of your vaginal health. Find probiotics that work for you and don’t hesitate to speak to your gyn if you have any questions. Also my acne did flare up but I’ve been on top of my skincare which seems to keep it at bay. I’d say kyleena is worth it but you just have to stick it out, check with your doctor about any concerns and stay on too if your general health.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I love the convenience of not needing to remember to take something but the mild to moderate pain was completely false for me. I’ve had multiple episodes of extreme cramping, usually when I’m supposed to get my period (my periods did stop after 2 months). I had them check and everything was inserted properly and the pain is supposed to go away by 6 months. It’s been 4 months and I still have bouts of horrible pain that leaves me curled up in a ball.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I’ve has Kyleena for 2 1/2 months.  I have a pretty high pain tolerance, and I have NEVER experienced something SO PAINFUL. There’s slight discomfort, and then two huge crampy pinches. After that was over I thought I’d be okay, but as I went to sit up and get situated my vision got blurry, and I became extremely nauseous. My blood pressure had gotten pretty low, which is why I was feeling so awful. I had terrible cramps the whole ride home. The cramps would come in waves, every 3 minutes or so the pain would hit and then would come back after 5 minutes or so. The only way I could alleviate some of the pain was to sit in a hot bath. But after the 3rd or 4th day the cramps weren’t as intense. I’ve had weight gain, and a few other issues since then. So. Every women is different, but if you tend to have sensitives to medications or change to your body this probably isn’t for you. I’m ready to have it removed, but am terrified of getting it removed.

Mirena (levonorgestrel):So I got the Mirena coil in after I had my daughter and everything was going ok until I found out I was pregnant again. I was taken straight in to hospital to have it removed and it couldn’t be found then I was told it had fallen out and to continue things as normal. Then I started bleeding really badly and sadly had a miscarriage. Had to go in for a scan to confirm this and they found the coil in my uterus. 3 attempts to try and catch the string through my cervix which was the most uncomfortable feeling. I now have to go back for an x-ray tomorrow and it looks like it is going to be surgery to remove it. I would never recommend this to anyone after my experience. I know nothings 100% but this has been a nightmare

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):My 1 year and 9 months with Kylenna inserted has been amazing, the only annoying part is my period is very irregular. With that said it's not that big of deal to me since it's extremely light now (previously my periods were extremely heavy). I highly recommend Kylenna, but everyone is different.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I got the Kyleena IUD inserted about a month ago and to say the least it is an unpleasant experience. The actual insertion is uncomfortable and some what painful. I felt a lot of cramping the rest of the day and the following 2 days. I thought after 2 days the cramps would go away, however the third day was the worst. I had such bad cramps I had to leave work and classes early. After the third day the cramps completely went away. Now it's been just over 4 weeks and I only feel cramps every once and a while and they only last about 20 minutes. Now I do not have to worry about taking my pill and despite the pain you have to go through I don't regret my decision at all. I am very happy with Kyleena and I highly recommend it. I suggest taking a few days off work and/or school if possible to let your body adjust. Other than that, Kyleena is a great choice to make.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):Have had Kyleena for almost 8 months. Got it because I was having abnormal bleeding on the pill. Spotted and had cramps for a few weeks after getting it but after that I stopped having periods altogether. Very painful insertion as well. Nearly passed out but then again I don't have the best pain tolerance. I would have rated it higher since it did it's job effectively, but ever since I got it I have had extreme depression and worsened anxiety. I did not have any mental health problems until getting the Kyleena. I even tried several antidepressants and mood stabilizers and nothing worked so I'm sure it's the IUD. Getting it removed soon thankfully. If you are sensitive to medications and hormones, make sure to do your research first and be prepared for possible side effects.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I had my IUD inserted yesterday. Just keep in mind we are all different. I am 21 and never had a baby. I took 2 advils 1hour before the appointment. It was the worst pain I have ever felt. The first pain was measuring the uterus and then after the insertion. It felt like a intense bad period cramp mixed with a feeling of being stab for about 30 second. I needed to take the bus to go back home it was not a good idea... I puked and had a lot of cramps, the road was making my cramps worst. I had a lot of hot flashes and had difficulty to walk. I had no energy for the rest of the evening.Today it feels like bad period cramps but only  here and there. I think it is worth the pain,2-3 days of pain for 5 years of contraception. Thats reasonable. I will update in a few month.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):This is my first time trying an IUD. I've always been on the pill but wanted to try something different. I went with Kyleena because it is more for women that have never given birth.I can't report on effectiveness yet since my insertion was today.I was on my period when I went in this morning but since insertion I have had NO bleeding at all!Now pain during insertion... for me it was extremely painful during insertion however the pain is short (15-20 seconds).I knew it was likely going to be painful but didnt realize how excruciating pain would be.Pain timeline----insertion: extremely painful, I would rate pain at 10/10 during insertion -right after insertion: pain rated at 5 or 6 -1 hour after insertion: pain very minimal. More just crampy feeling. -2.5 hours after insertion: no pain and able to head to work fine. 10-12 hours after insertion: a little more cramping.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):Skyla has been great. I tried many oral contraceptives and had a lot of side effects from all of them ( low sex drive, vaginal dryness, hair loss, weight gain, acne ). Skyla has given me no side effects and my sex drive is back to normal. Every woman is different and hormones will react differently for everyone but this has been a great option for me!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):So I wanted to wait to actually make a post about it. I’ve had it for about a month now. I haven’t dealt with this much pain in forever. My cramps on this are unbearable idk if anyone is going through this. Before I got it I never had cramps but as soon as I got it the cramps started. And the periods are constant which is very annoying because I got it thinking my periods would decrease but at this rate I’m probably going to get back on depo.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I've had Skyla for 2 years now and I absolutely love it! Although the initial insertion was painful, for me it's been totally worth it! The first 2 months were spotty and somewhat crampy, but then my body adjusted to it and has had no bad symptoms at all! My body expelled two Copper IUDs before, and Skyla was a last ditch effort to use an IUD and boy, am I happy it works for me! Not looking forward to getting it replaced, but in a year when I need a new one I will be choosing Skyla again!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I have had a great experience. Barely spotted, an occasional cramp, the insertion hurt more than I expected but wasn't awful. I forgot to take advil before. I am sure it would have helped. Overall it was a good decision.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I had my insertion less than a month ago. I'm 21, have never given birth. The insertion process was painful but brief. By the time your brain registers, "Hey! This really hurts!" it's already over and done with, often times. The rest of the day I was in a lot of pain. The pain was basically completely gone after day 3.So far I have consistent spotting typical for the first few months with occasional cramping. I have been getting pimples on my body in weird places, but not on my face. Not sure if this is related. One month in and I'm extremely happy. It has definitely improved sex between me and my partner as we have chosen to skip condoms in favor of the IUD and pull-out method. Don't let the stuff you read on the internet about IUDs scare you. Keep in mind people are more likely to share their experiences online if those experiences are negative or traumatic. In reality, the IUD reports high overall satisfaction.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I've had Kyleena for 1 year and 5 months now. I'm usually ALWAYS cramping whether its tolerable cramps or not. After 6 months went by of having it, some months I will have a very light period and some months I will have no period. It has made my discharge a lot heavier than what it was before I got it inserted, which is never fun because now I have to wear panty liners 99% of the time. I do recommend it though, there's more pro's than con's but it will effect everyone differently!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I've had Kyleena for about a month now and it's not bad! I've read a lot of reviews and I have advice for anyone thinking: do your research. Drugs are different for everybody. Sometimes you bleed for up to a month (this is normal) and sometimes it's all gone! (That's what happened for me) so you HAVE to talk to your provider about what you are expecting. Also: don't get it put in my just anyone. Get someone who has done this a lot. If you do that, it will be inserted relatively easily and definitely correctly. My experience has been pretty good! I am still spotting and cramping, but I'm still in the adjustment period, so it should subside after around 4 months max. Getting an IUD is a time commitment, but you have to think: is a couple cramps and spotting for a little while worse than having a baby that you're not ready for?

Mirena (levonorgestrel):I had Mirena inserted almost 7 years ago for birth control. I have to have it taken out soon and am kind of dreading it. I’ve gotten so used to not having my period and not having to worry about being pregnant!  I had mild cramping for a day after insertion, my biggest complaint was that I had some minor spotting for 4-6 months afterwards. Fortunately it wasn’t ever much to be concerned with- And gradually got less frequent to the point that the last 6 1/2 years I have not had my period except occasionally (like maybe twice a year) I’d spot for a day or two, I’d hardly even call it a period it was so little. Mirena is marketed as being effective for 5 years but the physicians assistant I saw maybe a year after said that research has shown it to be good for up to 7 and in Europe it’s marketed as 7. Overall I have been extremely satisfied.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I was TERRIFIED of getting an IUD. I had googled everything and even watched a YouTube video... My OBGYN gave me a pill to take the night before to soften my cervix and help dilate it. I HIGHLY recommend you ask for the pill especially if you’ve never had a baby before. It will make the procedure less painful and a lot easier. I took 4 ibruprofens before I went. I had only 2 big pinches and the insertion itself wasn’t painful at all. It was so worth it! After it was done I said Oh that’s it? I had some bleeding and very mild cramping for the rest of the day. I was 100% cramp and period free the next day. It’s only been 2 days but I’m already excited about it. I’m happy I never have to take a pill again and I’m happy my body reacted well to Kyleena. I wanted to write a review right away because I want other women/girls to know that it’s worth it... make sure to take pain medication beforehand and try to relax! Again, ask your doctor for that magic pill!!

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I have had three Mirenas. I decided to try out kyleena when the third mirena shifted out of place and had to be removed. The pros for both are no worries about remembering the pill and reduced period flow. I've seen a lot of newly minted individuals who have just started out on IUD's and wanted to offer a more long term perspective. One thing that has been a major difference is cramping. I never had bad cramping with mirena, but with this IUD I have to breathe through some of the cramps due to their intensity. It didn't give me much trouble when it was inserted, so if the focus of your concern is on this type of pain, you have less to consider. The jury is still out for me on this IUD. It's still relatively new compared to other IUDs and there isn't a lot of historical information out there about its long term use. I will say that knowing what I know now, I would have opted for Mirena if I had to make the choice again.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I've had my Kyleena for 3 months now. It's great because I don't have to remember to take a pill. Besides that, I haven't experienced anything else really all that positive. My body has had time to adapt. I don't have long periods, but they do last a week, and they still aren't regular. I spot for maybe 3 days, and then a week later have my period for 6 days. My acne (that used to be extremely minimal) is now much worse (and everywhere) and now I'm on an acne treatment. I get pretty bad cramping sporadically that I feel in my legs. I just feel like this just didn't work well for me and my body. I'm getting it removed in a few weeks, and going back to oral contraceptive. I paid $85 for Kyleena

Liletta (levonorgestrel):Date Placed: 04/18Today's Date: 9/12Still experiencing NEVER-ENDING SPOTTING.  When it was first placed everything was normal for a month but then I got a REALLY HEAVY FLOW for about 3 weeks and had to use Super Plus tampons. Once that finally stopped I had no bleeding for maybe two weeks. Now here I am with the BROWNISH REDDISH DISCHARGE. Has anyone else experienced any of these things?

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):***INSERTION ONLY*** I’m 34 years old, have never had kids but am interested in having them one day.  I was on LoLoestrin for 3 years and had terrible mood swings because of all of the hormones.  I decided to come off of the pill in June and my Doctor recommended Kyleena.  I had Kyleena inserted this morning and it definitely wasn’t as bad as I thought.  For weeks I’ve been working myself up about this, terrified about the pain of insertion.  I know it is different for everyone but for me it went much better than I was expecting.  I took 800mg of Ibuprofen an hour beforehand.  My doctor said one big cramp coming and that was it, a big cramp (definitely the strongest cramp I’ve ever felt) and then she said it was over!  I’m having light spotting now but so far, so good! I’ll update this in a few months to rate the long term experience :)

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I switched from birth control pill to birth control pill, all of which I had adverse reactions to such as mood swings, extremely low sex drives, weight gain, and painful sex. I finally decided to get an IUD and went with kyleena. The insertion was very painful for me and the most severe cramps occurred for the rest of the day. In the days that followed, the cramps subsided and a month later I don’t even know it’s there! I have no mood swings and my sex drive has finally returned so I can enjoy my sex life again. I had no spotting either. I recommend this to anyone who has any issues with the pill and other types of birth control.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):So I have had an interesting experience so far. I had skyla placed about 7-8 months ago. I use birth control for obvious reasons, however also for heavy long periods. Skyla caused lots of spotting for me. Periods have gotten lighter, however spotting did not ease up. Going in again in a month to look into other options because I bleed more days out of the month than not. wouldn’t be my first choice in birth control.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I have used Skyla since April of 2018 . The insertion process was not as bad as I had  read from other blogs. Just felt like a bad cramp and it was quickly done. I got it during my cycle and bled for a few weeks after that. I had mild cramps for the week after insertion. I haven’t had major side effects -  just dry skin for most of the past for which I have found a good moisturizer. I have gained 4 lbs since insertion. Overall this has been a good journey and I love my Skyla

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I got my IUD placed 3 wks ago. The placement was not as bad as most of these reviews suggest. It was just a really uncomfortable feeling. Not so much pain other than a slight pinch but it was bearable. After the placement ( at 1:15 pm) I had cramps for the rest of the day until I fell asleep, the cramps were also bearabe. They came in waves ( cramp for 30 sec, then I'd be fine for 5-10 mins, & then another cramp would start). It really just felt like you had a tampon suck up there. I was taking Advil & t3's although that together didn't totally subside the cramps. I've had no bleeding in general or from sex. My partner has not been able to feel the strings. At the 3 week mark, I'm having those same kind of cramps again, & I had one day of light spotting. My boobs grew a whole cup size within a week. I had to go out & buy new bras because my other ones won't fit. Also my boobs are extremely tender & sore + the cramps  suck but other than that the kyleena IUD has been good.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):I've had the device for two years now. The first year was great hardly any side effects only abnormal cycles but that was a given. Now I see hardly any menses but the issue I have with the device is my face is breaking out, my hormones are all wack, I can't lose weight and my breast get so sore and painful it is the worst. I plan to remove the device soon. Also I've experienced hair loss

Mirena (levonorgestrel):Insertion wasn't exactly painful.  The measuring of my uterus felt extremely weird.  It was inserted on the first day of my cycle (August 31st) and I have been bleeding/spotting since.  Cramps started about an hour after insertion.  Took 800mg ibuprofen for the next two days.  Random cramping every now and then, but its not horrible.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I love it so far. It was uncomfortable of course but it was not painful when I had it inserted.  It took less than five minutes. I got itput in during the six week check  after I had my baby, which is recommended. No complaints so far and no weight gain. I've maintained my weight.

Liletta (levonorgestrel):I am 25 no kids never had BC I got liletta about 3 months ago. Insertion wasn’t that bad. I took some pain pills before I went. It was like a really bad cramp and only lasted a few minutes. Afterwards I didn’t bleed at all for a week and then I was spotting every day for about a month. I’m going into my 3rd month and have not had a period since getting it at all. I cramped so badly for an entire month. I had to carry Advil with me everywhere I went. But after the first month passed they settled down. Now on month 3 the cramps are very rare. The 1st month my skin was awful I was depressed and had so many mood swings that 1st month. And now at the 3rd month I am noticing the breast tenderness everyone mentions. I also have like a really thick clear jellylike discharge. I’m still  waiting for my first period while having the IUD.  (I’ve taken pregnancy tests so I know that’s not it) but now that the cramps have settled I’m a lot happier with my IUD.

Kyleena (levonorgestrel):It's definitely effective but not a 10. I'm 18 and  never had a child. The insertion wasn't as bad as anticipated but that was only because my nurse was talking to take my mind off it but I felt a big pinch and a cramp and it was in; not an hour later I was in unbearable immobilizing pain which lasted for the first 4 months. I couldn't lay on my belly because I would cramp up and I couldn't lay on my sides because I would actually feel the IUD poking me. Since then I only get unbearable cramps 4 days before my period and maybe a couple here and there during. They usually last about 30 seconds but normal pain meds like ibuprofen couldn't even calm them down. The last few months kyleena has given me constant infections (yeast and BV)  I have mood swings. My periods are even more annoying now they are lighter but it seems like it never stops, and the blood rarely even looks like blood. I would not recommend even to my worst enemy.

Skyla (levonorgestrel):I have had my Skyla for almost the three years now and I am absolutely replacing it in just a couple months. Insertion was actually a miserable process for me personally-took 3 appointments (your cervix has to measure a certain size and that's the painful part...measuring). However, before the 3rd appointment, I was given a cervix dilator and that made the 3rd attempt take all of 5 minutes. I advise some ibuprofen/tylenol beforehand because you might have some cramping afterward. I've never had miserable periods anyway so I can't say it affected it too much other than they are a bit lighter now. Also, cost can be an issue because its not cheap; I was very fortunate to be in nursing school at the time so it was completely free..but it is a long term solution if it works for you. Finding birth control is tricky and I was fortunate to find the perfect one for my body on the first try

Skyla (levonorgestrel):Got Sklya inserted on 7/27/18. Wow, that was painful.
